children.name: standardize
children.definition: alsostandardiseBritish /ˈstændəʳdaɪz/  to make sure that a particular type of product, service, activity etc is always made or done in exactly the same way: chuẩn hóa
examples: ▪ They are standardising all the equipment throughout the area and bringing it up to British Standards safety requirements.
▪ At first there were several competing designs of electric plug-sockets, but these were standardized in the 1920s.

children.name: bring sth into line
children.definition: bring something into line with/ˌbrɪŋ something ɪntə ˈlaɪn wɪð/  to change something such as a rule or system so that it is the same as another generally accepted rule or system:
examples: ▪ Our wage levels should be brought into line with those of our competitors.
▪ There have been calls for the total abolition of car tax, which would bring car prices into line with those in the rest of Europe.

children.name: the same in value, position, effect, etc
corresponding
children.definition: having similar qualities or a similar size, position etc to something elseSYN equivalent:tương ứng
examples: Sales are up 10% on the corresponding period last year.
Compared with the corresponding period last year, average temperatures have been low.
The removal of American nuclear forces brought a corresponding withdrawal of Russian troops.
A big fall in steel productivity caused a corresponding decrease in profits.
—correspondinglyadverb:
As his political power has shrunk, he has grown correspondingly more dependent on the army.

children.name: equivalent
children.definition: having the same value, purpose, job etc as a person or thing of a different kind:tương đương
examples: He was fined $50 but given the choice of doing the equivalent amount of community work.
The US Congress is roughly equivalent to the British Parliament.
equivalent to
a qualification which is equivalent to a degree
I had no dollars, but offered him an equivalent amount of sterling.
His monthly US salary is equivalent to a year’s pay here in Mexico.

children.name: the same in amount number or size, etc
the same
children.definition: /ðə ˈseɪm/  giống
examples: ▪ Both stores are charging the same price for CD players
the same height/age/price etc as
▪ Her sister is the same age as me
▪ For much the same price as a flat in London, you can buy a luxury home in Barnsley.
exactly the same height/age/price etc
▪ We’re both exactly the same height.

children.name: be as old as
children.definition: be as old/long/strong etc as/biː əz; ˈəʊld əz/  to be the same age, length etc as someone or something else:tương đương, như nhau
examples: ▪ At 14, Richard was already as tall as his father
be as old/long/strong etc as : cũ/dài/mạnh như nhau
▪ The loss of a pet can be just as upsetting as the death of a member of the family.

children.name: equal
children.definition: the same in size, number, amount, value etc as something else:bằng nhau, tương đương
examples: You should spend an equal amount of time on each question in the test.
equal number/amount (of something)
Both candidates received an equal number of votes.
(of) equal value/importance
They believe that all work is of equal value.
equal in size/length/height etc
The two towns are roughly equal in size.
of equal size/length/height etc
equal to
The rent was equal to half his monthly income.

children.name: exactly equal
examples: The food is shared out in exactly equal portions among all members of the community.

children.name: roughly/approximately equal
examples: The number of buyers and sellers must be roughly equal before trading begins.

children.name: about/almost equal
examples: They are about equal in height and weight.

children.name: an equal number/amount
examples: Both candidates received an equal number of votes.

children.name: be of equal size/length/height etc
examples: Draw two lines of equal length.

children.name: be equal in size/length/height etc
examples: The population of each town is roughly equal in size.

children.name: be equal in value
examples: Your pension will be equal in value to two thirds of your final year salary.

children.name: be equal in number/numbers
examples: In higher education, women are equal in numbers to men.

children.name: of equal value/importance
examples: He is remembered for his novels, but his scientific work is of equal importance.

children.name: equally[adverb]
examples: C1 to the same degree:
Both schools seem equally good.
Club bosses and doormen are equally concerned about the situation.

children.name: the same in all its parts
uniform
children.definition: /ˈjuːnɪfɔːʳm, ˈjuːnəfɔːʳm/  a thing or group that is uniform has the same appearance or characteristics in all its parts: đồng nhất
examples: ▪ The temperature must be uniform in every area of the reactor.
▪ The postal system operates a uniform price structure, so it always costs the same to send a letter
uniform in
▪ Grade A vegetables have to be uniform in size and without marks or blemishes.Loại rau A phải có kích thước và không có dấu hiệu hoặc nhược điểm.
uniformly[adverb] thống nhất
▪ Throughout the industry the standard of product is uniformly high
uniformity/ˌjuːnɪˈfɔːʳməti, ˌjuːnəˈfɔːʳməti/ [uncountable noun] tính đồng nhất
▪ Most modern housing developments show a tedious uniformity of design..

children.name: homogeneous
children.definition: /ˌhəʊməˈdʒiːniəs/  formal having the same characteristics in every part, so that every single person or thing in a group is the same: đồng nhất
examples: ▪ Women are not a homogeneous group.
▪ Computers check whether each text is stylistically homogeneous.

children.name: the same
children.definition: the same place, person, or thing, not a different one: giống, như nhau
examples: ▪ My friend and I went to the same school.
▪ They work in different offices, but they have the same boss.
▪ He could hardly believe that the woman sitting in front of him was the same one he’d seen on TV so many times
the same ... as
▪ She was born on the same day as me.
▪ I was staying in the same hotel as Nelson Mandela. Can you believe it!

children.name: common
children.definition: two or more people who have common aims, interests, beliefs etc have the same interests, aims, or beliefs: cùng chung cái gì
examples: ▪ We have a common goal - the creation of a united Europe.
▪ Dating agencies try to match people with similar personalities and common interests.

children.name: common groundopinions, beliefs etc shared between people
examples: ▪ There was a great deal of common ground between all the different representatives.

children.name: the self-same
children.definition: the very (same)//ðə ˌveri (ˈseɪm), ðə ˈself seɪm/  use this to emphasize that someone or something is the same person or thing, not a different one, when this is interesting or surprising:giống nhau
examples: ▪ This is the very same house where Shakespeare wrote most of his plays.
▪ Television gets most of its stories from the very tabloid newspapers it is so fond of attacking.
▪ The self-same people who complain about low-flying aircraft are the ones who will be jetting off to Florida on their holidays next year.

children.name: when facts, numbers,situations are the same
correspond
children.definition: if facts or situations correspond, they are the same as each other or have the same effect: tương ứng
examples: ▪ The dates quoted in these two documents do not correspond.

children.name: correspond with
examples: ▪ The witness’s statements correspond with the available evidence.

children.name: correspond to
examples: ▪ His own domestic situation did not correspond very closely to his ideal of a loving, equal partnership.

children.name: consistent
children.definition: be  with if sth that is said, written, or done is consistent with a particular idea or piece of information, it says the same thing or follows the same principles: "nhất quán"
examples: ▪ The figures in the accounts must be consistent with the information given in the annual report.
▪ Charging these very high fines is hardly consistent with your policy of "user-friendly banking'.
▪ This sort of repression is not consistent with a democratic system.

children.name: agree
children.definition: if two pieces of information agree with each other, they are the same, and so they are both likely to be correct:
examples: ▪ I’ll have to check these calculations again -- the totals don’t agree.

children.name: agree with
examples: ▪ Your story doesn’t agree with what the police have told us.

children.name: tally
children.definition: /ˈtæli/  if a piece of information tallies with another, they are the same; if two sets of numbers tally, they add up to the same thing.:đều giống nhau
examples: ▪ Check both sets of results to see if they tally.
tally with hợp với
▪ His account of the discovery of the body tallied with the testimony of his wife

children.name: coincide
children.definition: if two people’s ideas, opinions, or wishes coincide, they are the same, even though this may be completely by chance: đều giống nhau, trùng hợp
examples: ▪ For once our wishes coincided. We both wanted a quick divorce.

children.name: coincide with
examples: ▪ His views coincided perfectly with our thinking.
▪ Even if her advice does not coincide with what you want, I advise you to follow it.

children.name: match up
children.definition: if information from one place matches up with information from another, both sets of information are the same, which shows that they are both correct: phù hợp, khớp
examples: ▪ I’ve questioned both suspects and so far their stories just don’t match up. One of them must be lying.

children.name: match up with
examples: ▪ You must make sure that your sales figures match up with your receipts at the end of each week.

children.name: to make you think of another similar person or thing
remind
children.definition: somebody of/rɪˈmaɪnd somebody ɒv/  to make you think of another thing or person because they are similar:
examples: ▪ Sometimes, when you’re angry, you remind me of your father.
▪ The way he tells jokes reminds me of Jonathan.
▪ What an ugly little building! It reminds me of a public lavatory.

children.name: reminiscent
children.definition: be  of formal ifsb/sthis reminiscent of another thing or person, they make you think of that other thing or person because they have a similar style, appearance, sound etc:gợi lại, làm nhớ lại
examples: His singing is reminiscent of Bob Marley.
The Senator spoke of the drama of the situation in tones reminiscent of an evangelical preacher.
Her style of writing is somewhat reminiscent of Virginia Woolf.

children.name: echo
children.definition: formal if something, especially a performance or a work of art echoessththat existed in the past, it makes you think of it because it is similar:lặp lại
examples: ▪ This new musical with its expensive costumes and scenery echoes the Hollywood glamour of the 1950s.
▪ Her designs were informed by vintage Halston, ‘Love Story’ and the leisure suit, all echoing 1970s’ style.

children.name: the same
children.definition: ▪ They were both wearing  shoes.
examples: ▪ We’ve opened up stores in the UK and we hope to do the same in the rest of Europe.
▪ ‘We always get up late on Saturdays.’ ‘It’s the same in our house.’
look/sound/taste etc the same
▪ The houses on the street all look the same.
just the same/exactly the samenot different in any way y như nhau
▪ I tried three different types of wine, but they all tasted exactly the same to me.
all the same
▪ Take whichever you like - they’re all the same.
the same ... as
▪ They were doing the same jobs as the men, but being paid less.
much the same/ˌmʌtʃ ðə ˈseɪm/ [adjective phrase] very similar:
▪ Soldiers are much the same throughout the world.
much the same as
▪ Bodie looks much the same as the day the mines closed down.
much the same....as/that
▪ The glass is still made in much the same way as it was 100 years ago.
▪ The warranty would cover the electric car’s battery pack in much the same way that gasoline engines are protected.
look/feel/smell/taste much the same
▪ All these wines taste much the same.

children.name: just like
children.definition: /exactly like if someone or something is just like or exactly like someone or something else, there is very little difference between them: giống y như
examples: ▪ You’re just like my teacher.
▪ There are insects that look exactly like green leaves.
▪ This song sounds exactly like that one by The Beatles.
be just/exactly like doing sth
▪ We had often talked about emigrating to Australia. Suzie came from Melbourne, so it would be just like going home for her

children.name: identical
children.definition: identical things are exactly the same in every way: giống hệt nhau
examples: ▪ To me the two patterns looked identical.

children.name: identical to
examples: ▪ The picture is identical to the one in the museum of Modern Art in New York.

children.name: identical in size/colour/shape etc
examples: ▪ The tablets were identical in size, shape, and colour.

children.name: can’t tell the difference
children.definition: /can’t tell them apart if you can’t tell the difference between two people or things, or if you can’t tell them apart, they look, sound, or seem exactly the same to you: không thể phân biệt
examples: ▪ Emma and Louise sound so alike on the phone, I can’t tell the difference.
▪ They are identical twins and it’s impossible to tell them apart.
▪ These rap bands all sound the same to me -- I can’t tell them apart.

children.name: can’t tell the difference between
examples: ▪ Don’t let her help you with the gardening -- she can’t tell the difference between a weed and a strawberry plant!

children.name: indistinguishable
children.definition: two people or things that are indistinguishable are so similar that it is impossible to know which is which or to see any differences between them: không thể phân biệt được
examples: ▪ In the storm the sky and sea were indistinguishable.
▪ It was claimed that Russian and American defence policies were indistinguishable.

children.name: indistinguishable from
examples: ▪ He tasted the cheaper wine and found it indistinguishable from a superior one.

children.name: be no different U
children.definition: be no different from use this especially when you expect sb/sth to be different from another thing or person, but in fact they are the same:không khác gì
examples: ▪ People often think that movie stars are special in some way, but really they’re no different from anybody else.
▪ Life on the island is no different from life on the mainland.

children.name: match
children.definition: if one thing matches another or if two things match, they look the same or have the same qualities or characteristics: giống nhau, hợp, khớp

children.name: ▪ You can’t go out wearing socks that don’t match
examples: ▪ Their performance in government didn’t quite match their election promises.

children.name: word for word
children.definition: if you repeat or copy something word for word, you do it using exactly the same words: chính xác
examples: ▪ Janice repeated word for word what Harold had told her.

children.name: ▪ It appears that someone has copied your essay word for word
like
children.definition: /laɪk/  similar to something or someone:
examples: ▪ The houses here are like the ones in northern France.
▪ My mother has a car like yours.
look/feel/sound/smell/taste like
▪ She laughed like a child and played with her hair.
▪ This is such beautiful material - it feels like silk.
▪ It looks a bit like a cactus.
something like
fairly similar
▪ This superb almost-flourless chocolate cake is something like a brownie for grownups.
nothing like
not at all similar
▪ Life at college was nothing like I expected.

children.name: similar
children.definition: /ˈsɪmələʳ, ˈsɪmɪləʳ/  if one thing is similar to another, or if two or more things are similar, they are like each other:
examples: ▪ I know how you feel, because I have a similar problem.
▪ It’s bigger than Jim’s room, but it’s very similar.
▪ When you look at these two carpets, you can see that the patterns are very similar.

children.name: similar to
examples: ▪ Do you have anything similar to this material but cheaper?
▪ The Marines also experimented with fast-attack vehicles, similar to dune buggies.

children.name: alike
children.definition: /əˈlaɪk/  if two or more things or people are alike, they are very similar in some way:
examples: ▪ You lawyers are all alike. You just talk a lot, tell a few lies, and send the bill.
▪ I think my mother and I are very much alike in some ways.
▪ As the personal computer market matured, computer makers have realized that not all PC buyers are alike.

children.name: look/think/sound etc alike
examples: ▪ The album is boring - all of their songs sound alike.

children.name: resemble
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: /bear a resemblance toC2  to be similar in appearance or character:
examples: ▪ Geraldine resembled her mother in every way.
▪ Addis Ababa soon resembled an armed camp.

children.name: closely resemble
examples: ▪ We have produced a cloth made of pineapple fibre, closely resembling cotton but stronger.

children.name: bear a strong/close/striking resemblance to
examples: ▪ She’s seventy-six, short, round and fair, and bears a strong resemblance to my own grandmother.

children.name: bear some/little/no resemblance to
examples: ▪ The London of the new millennium bears little resemblance to the London of my youth.

children.name: comparable
children.definition: /ˈkɒmpərəbəlǁˈkɑːm-/  similar in size, number, quality etc so that a comparison is possible:
examples: ▪ Climatic conditions in the two countries are roughly comparable.

children.name: comparable with/to
examples: ▪ The size of a dolphin’s brain is comparable to a human’s.

children.name: comparable in size/importance etc
examples: ▪ The planet Pluto is comparable in size to our Moon.

children.name: akin
children.definition: to/əˈkɪn tuː/  if something is akin to something else, it is very similar to it in character - used especially in literature:
examples: ▪ It’s a language closely akin to Arabic, and most Syrians would understand it.
▪ It was with a feeling akin to despair that I realized the car was not going to start.

children.name: like
children.definition: /laɪk/  in a similar way to someone or something:
examples: ▪ I’d love to be able to sing like Ella Fitzgerald.
▪ You’re treating him like a child.
▪ Huge trees had snapped like matchsticks in the hurricane-force winds.
▪ Like many women her age, she struggled to find a balance between her career and her children.

children.name: just/exactly like something
examples: ▪ She moves and talks exactly like her mother.

children.name: similarly
children.definition: /ˈsɪmɪləʳli/  formal:
examples: ▪ The son followed his father’s example and, similarly, the daughter modelled herself on her mother.

children.name: similarly situated/expressed/inclined etc
examples: ▪ San Francisco and Rio de Janeiro are similarly situated, both standing at the entrance to great natural harbours.
▪ This idea of creation is similarly expressed in a poem by Dylan Thomas.

children.name: alike
children.definition: in a similar way
examples: The twins even dress alike.
My father treated us all alike.

children.name: the same
children.definition: in the same way
examples: We treat all our children the same.
I need some time to myself, the sameasanybody else.

children.name: in line with sth
children.definition: in line withsth

children.name: to be similar to, or at the same level as something
examples: _The company's results are in line with stock market expectations.
_We're seeking a pay rise that's in line with inflation.
_The salaries of temporary employees ought to bebrought intoline with those of permanent staff.

children.name: overlap
children.definition: verb-pp-
examples: [ I ] If two or more activities, subjects or periods of time overlap, they
have someparts which are the same
_My musical tastes don't overlapwithmy brother's at all.

children.name: similar and equally good or bad
little to choose between
children.definition: there is /there is not much to choose between/ðeər ɪz ˌlɪtl tə ˈtʃuːz bɪtwiːn, ðeər ɪz ˌnɒt mʌtʃ tə ˈtʃuːz bɪtwiːn/ if there is little to choose between two or more people or things, they are almost equally good or bad, especially so that you would not know which one to choose:
examples: ▪ There’s very little to choose between the two apartments in terms of space, so I think we should take the cheaper one.
▪ When you look at the two candidates, there really isn’t much to choose between them.

children.name: much of a muchness
children.definition: be /biː ˌmʌtʃ əv ə ˈmʌtʃns/  British informal to be very similar and almost equally good or bad:
examples: ▪ I can’t really recommend any particular hotel. They’re all much of a muchness.

children.name: two of a kind
children.definition: be  if two people are two of a kind, they are very similar to each other in character or behaviour:tuy hai mà một
examples: You’re two of a kind, you and Doug - you can never be serious for even one minute!
They were two of a kind, both proud and stubborn, both hated by the community.

children.name: have a lot in common
children.definition: / have so much in common two or more people who have a lot in common share similar interests, attitudes, tastes etc:
examples: We like the same things and the same people. I think we have a lot in common.
You two have so much in common. You should be able to find a way to talk about things without fighting.

children.name: analogy
children.definition: nounsự tương tự; sự giống nhau

children.name: a comparison between things which have similar features, often used to help explain aprinciple or idea
examples: _Hedrewan analogybetweenthe brain and a vast computer.
_It is sometimes easier to illustrate an abstract conceptbyanalogywith(= by comparing it with) something concrete.

children.name: It's the same old story
children.definition: .informal

children.name: said when talking about a bad situation which has happened many times before
examples: _It's the same old story - the rich getricher and the poor get poorer.

children.name: likewise
children.definition: adverbnhư thế, tương tự như vậy

children.name: in the same way
examples: _Just water these plants twice a week, and likewise the ones in the bedroom.

children.name: _informal"I haven't got time to spend hours preparing one dish!" "Likewise (= It's the same for me) ."
equal
children.definition: having the same rights, opportunities etc as everyone else, whatever your race, religion, or sex :
examples: Our constitution states that all men are equal.
Our education system should provideequal opportunitiesfor all children.
The government is committed to achievingequal rightsfor women.

children.name: equal rights
examples: In many countries, women do not have equal rights with men.

children.name: equal opportunities
examples: The government must make sure that all children have equal opportunities in education.

children.name: equal pay
examples: The workers’ demands include equal pay for equal work.

children.name: equal access
children.definition: the same right to do or receive something
examples: The law states that disabled people must have equal access to employment.

children.name: equal treatment
examples: Everyone should get equal treatment under the law.

children.name: be born equal
examples: It is a myth that all men are born equal.

children.name: be created equal
examples: They believe that everyone is created equal by God.

children.name: parallel
children.definition: adjectiveSIMILARtương đương; tương tựsong song
examples: describes an event or situation that happens at the same time as and/or is similar to another one
_a parallel example
_Parallel experiments are being conducted inRome,ParisandLondon.

children.name: close
children.definition: adjectiveSIMILARrất giống

children.name: having only a small difference
examples: _The election results were so close they had to vote again.
_He came second in the race, but it was very close.
_The youngest boys are so closeinage they look like twins.
_Both children bear a very closeresemblanceto their father.

children.name: along the lines of sth
children.definition: along the lines ofsth(alsoalong those lines)

children.name: similar in type
examples: _I was thinking of doing a meal along the lines of that dinner I did for Annie and Dave.

children.name: _They're campaigning for the electoral system to be reformed along the lines of (= so that it
examples: becomes similar to) the one inGermany.

children.name: or sth like that
children.definition: or something (like that)informal

children.name: used to show that what you have just said is only an example or you are not certain about it
examples: _She works for a bank or something.
_Why don't you go to a movie or something?

children.name: neck and neck
children.definition: If two competitors are , they are level with each other and have an equal chance of winning.

children.name: equally
children.definition: adverbbằng nhau; đều nhau; như nhau

children.name: to the same degree
examples: _You looked equally nice in both dresses.

children.name: as
children.definition: conjunctionLIKEnhư

children.name: in the same way
examples: _He got divorced,(just)as his parents had done years before.
_This year, as in previous years, tickets sold very quickly.
_Aswithhis earlier movies, the special effects in his latest film are brilliant.
_Asisoften the case with children, Amy was completely better by the time the doctor arrived.
_As I was just saying, I think the proposal needs further consideration.
_Knowing him as I do, I can't believe he would do such a thing.

children.name: equivalent
children.definition: noun

children.name: something which has the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc as something else
examples: _There is no English equivalentfor'bon appetit' so we have adopted the French expression.
_Ten thousand people a year die of the disease – that's the equivalentofthe population of this town.

children.name: like
children.definition: preposition,conjunctionAS IFnhư thể

children.name: in a way that suggests
examples: _Itlookslike I'm going to be in the office until late tonight.
_It looks like rain (= I think it is going to rain) .
_Itsoundsto me like you ought to change jobs.
_You look like you've just got out of bed!
_not standardShe acts like she's stupid!

children.name: so
children.definition: adverbSAME WAY
examples: used usually before the verbs 'have', 'be' or 'do', and otherauxiliary verbsto express the meaning 'in the same way' or 'in a similar way'
_"I've got an enormous amount of work to do." "So have I."
_"I'm allergic to nuts." "So is my brother."
_Neil left just after midnight and so did Roz.
_Justasyou like to have a night out with the lads, so I like to go out with the girls now and
again.

children.name: the same
children.definition: not another different thing or situation
examples: _I'm hopeless at physics, andit'sthe samewithchemistry - I get it all wrong.
the same thing
the same
_Training isn't the same thingaseducation.

children.name: alike
children.definition: adverb như nhau

children.name: used after referring to two groups of people or things to show that both groups areincluded
examples: _Friends and family alike were devastated by the news of her death.

children.name: such
children.definition: predeterminer,determiner,pronoun

children.name: of a particular or similar type
examples: _Small companies suchasours are very vulnerable in a recession.
_I'm looking for a cloth for cleaning silver. Do you have sucha thing?
_Present on this grand occasion were Andrew Davies, Melissa Peters and other such stars.
_I tried to tell her in sucha way thatshe wouldn't be offended.
_He said it was an Edwardian washstand orsomesuch thing - I can't remember exactly.
_old-fashioned informalI just bought one or two things - bread and milkandsuch (alsosuchlike).
_formalOur lunch was such (= of a type) that we don't really need an evening meal.

children.name: not make any difference
children.definition: (alsonot make the slightest difference)

children.name: to not change a situation in any way
examples: _You can ask him again if you like, but it won't make any difference - he'll still say no.
_It makes no differencewhere you put the aerial, the TV picture's still lousy.

children.name: as though
children.definition: như thể, cứ như là

children.name: as if
examples: _You look as though you've had a bad time!
